articles.title: Scientists just made the first time crystal you can see
articles.summary: Physicists at the University of Colorado Boulder have created the first time crystal that humans can actually see, using liquid crystals that swirl into never-ending patterns when illuminated by light. This breakthrough builds on Nobel laureate Frank Wilczek’s 2012 theory of time crystals—structures that move forever in repeating cycles, like a perpetual motion machine or looping GIF. Under the microscope, these crystals form colorful, striped patterns that dance endlessly, opening possibilities for everything from anti-counterfeiting features in money to futuristic methods of storing digital information.
articles.content:
Imagine a clock that doesn't have electricity, but its hands and gears spin on their own for all eternity.

In a new study, physicists at the University of Colorado Boulder have used liquid crystals, the same materials that are in your phone display, to create such a clock -- or, at least, as close as humans can get to that idea. The team's advancement is a new example of a "time crystal." That's the name for a curious phase of matter in which the pieces, such as atoms or other particles, exist in constant motion.

The researchers aren't the first to make a time crystal, but their creation is the first that humans can actually see, which could open a host of technological applications.

"They can be observed directly under a microscope and even, under special conditions, by the naked eye," said Hanqing Zhao, lead author of the study and a graduate student in the Department of Physics at CU Boulder.

He and Ivan Smalyukh, professor of physics and fellow with the Renewable and Sustainable Energy Institute (RASEI), published their findings Sept. 4 in the journal Nature Materials.

In the study, the researchers designed glass cells filled with liquid crystals -- in this case, rod-shaped molecules that behave a little like a solid and a little like a liquid. Under special circumstances, if you shine a light on them, the liquid crystals will begin to swirl and move, following patterns that repeat over time.

Under a microscope, these liquid crystal samples resemble psychedelic tiger stripes, and they can keep moving for hours -- similar to that eternally spinning clock.

"Everything is born out of nothing," Smalyukh said. "All you do is shine a light, and this whole world of time crystals emerges."

Zhao and Smalyukh are members of the Colorado satellite of the International Institute for Sustainability with Knotted Chiral Meta Matter (WPI-SKCM2) with headquarters at Hiroshima University in Japan, an international institute with missions to create artificial forms of matter and contribute to sustainability.

Crystals in space and time

Time crystals may sound like something out of science fiction, but they take their inspiration from naturally occurring crystals, such as diamonds or table salt.

Nobel laureate Frank Wilczek first proposed the idea of time crystals in 2012. You can think of traditional crystals as "space crystals." The carbon atoms that make up a diamond, for example, form a lattice pattern in space that is very hard to break apart. Wilczek wondered if it would be possible to build a crystal that was similarly well organized, except in time rather than space. Even in their resting state, the atoms in such a state wouldn't form a lattice pattern, but would move or transform in a never-ending cycle -- like a GIF that loops forever.

Wilczek's original concept proved impossible to make, but, in the years since, scientists have created phases of matter that get reasonably close.

In 2021, for example, physicists used Google's Sycamore quantum computer to create a special network of atoms. When the team gave those atoms a flick with a laser beam, they underwent fluctuations that repeated multiple times.

Dancing crystals

In the new study, Zhao and Smalyukh set out to see if they could achieve a similar feat with liquid crystals.

Smalyukh explained that if you squeeze on these molecules in the right way, they will bunch together so tightly that they form kinks. Remarkably, these kinks move around and can even, under certain conditions, behave like atoms.

"You have these twists, and you can't easily remove them," Smalyukh said. "They behave like particles and start interacting with each other."

In the current study, Smalyukh and Zhao sandwiched a solution of liquid crystals in between two pieces of glass that were coated with dye molecules. On their own, these samples mostly sat still. But when the group hit them with a certain kind of light, the dye molecules changed their orientation and squeezed the liquid crystals. In the process, thousands of new kinks suddenly formed.

Those kinks also began interacting with each other following an incredibly complex series of steps. Think of a room filled with dancers in a Jane Austen novel. Pairs break apart, spin around the room, come back together, and do it all over again. The patterns in time were also unusually hard to break -- the researchers could raise or lower the temperature of their samples without disrupting the movement of the liquid crystals.

"That's the beauty of this time crystal," Smalyukh said. "You just create some conditions that aren't that special. You shine a light, and the whole thing happens."

Zhao and Smalyukh say that such time crystals could have several uses. Governments could, for example, add these materials to bills to make them harder to counterfeit -- if you want to know if that $100 bill is genuine, just shine a light on the "time watermark" and watch the pattern that appears. By stacking several different time crystals, the group can create even more complicated patterns, which could potentially allow engineers to store vast amounts of digital data.

"We don't want to put a limit on the applications right now," Smalyukh said. "I think there are opportunities to push this technology in all sorts of directions."

articles.personality_title: Scientists create the first time crystal visible to the naked eye
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists have long studied crystals, which are solid materials with atoms arranged in patterns. In 2012, a scientist named Frank Wilczek suggested a new type called "time crystals." Unlike regular crystals that are fixed in space, time crystals move in repeating cycles forever. Until now, these time crystals were too small or hidden to see without special tools.

**What happened** – Researchers at the University of Colorado Boulder used liquid crystals—the same materials in phone screens—to make a time crystal that people can actually see. They put liquid crystals between glass and shined a special light on them. This made the crystals swirl in colorful, striped patterns that keep moving endlessly, like a looping animation. Their work was published in September 2023.

**Impact** – This is the first time a time crystal’s movement can be seen by the naked eye. It shows a new way to create materials that keep changing in a predictable pattern without stopping. Such crystals could be used to make money harder to fake by adding moving patterns visible only under light. They might also help store lots of digital information in small spaces, offering new tools for technology.

**What's next step** – The scientists plan to explore more ways to use these visible time crystals. They want to build more complex patterns by stacking crystals and discover other practical applications. This research could lead to new materials for security and data storage in the future.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For the first time, scientists have made a time crystal that people can see, opening new possibilities for secure money and advanced data storage.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des scientifiques créent le premier cristal temporel visible à l'œil nu
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient depuis longtemps les cristaux, des solides dont les atomes sont arrangés en motifs. En 2012, le scientifique Frank Wilczek a proposé un nouveau type appelé « cristaux temporels ». Contrairement aux cristaux ordinaires fixes dans l’espace, ces cristaux bougent en cycles répétés à l’infini. Jusqu’à présent, ces cristaux temporels étaient trop petits ou cachés pour être vus sans outils spéciaux.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Des chercheurs de l’Université du Colorado à Boulder ont utilisé des cristaux liquides — les mêmes matériaux que dans les écrans de téléphone — pour créer un cristal temporel visible à l’œil nu. Ils ont placé les cristaux liquides entre deux morceaux de verre et ont éclairé le tout d’une lumière spéciale. Cela a fait tourner les cristaux en motifs rayés colorés qui bougent sans fin, comme une animation en boucle. Leur travail a été publié en septembre 2023.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que le mouvement d’un cristal temporel est visible sans microscope. Cela montre une nouvelle façon de créer des matériaux qui changent selon un motif prévisible sans s’arrêter. Ces cristaux pourraient rendre les billets de banque plus difficiles à falsifier grâce à des motifs mouvants visibles sous lumière. Ils pourraient aussi aider à stocker beaucoup d’informations numériques dans de petits espaces.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques veulent explorer d’autres usages pour ces cristaux temporels visibles. Ils souhaitent créer des motifs plus complexes en superposant plusieurs cristaux et trouver d’autres applications pratiques. Cette recherche pourrait mener à de nouveaux matériaux pour la sécurité et le stockage de données.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Pour la première fois, des scientifiques ont fabriqué un cristal temporel visible, ouvrant des possibilités pour sécuriser l’argent et stocker des données avancées.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos crean el primer cristal temporal visible a simple vista
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos han estudiado durante mucho tiempo los cristales, que son materiales sólidos con átomos organizados en patrones. En 2012, un científico llamado Frank Wilczek propuso un nuevo tipo llamado “cristales temporales”. A diferencia de los cristales normales que están fijos en el espacio, los cristales temporales se mueven en ciclos repetitivos para siempre. Hasta ahora, estos cristales eran demasiado pequeños o invisibles sin herramientas especiales.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores de la Universidad de Colorado Boulder usaron cristales líquidos — los mismos materiales que en las pantallas de los teléfonos — para crear un cristal temporal que las personas pueden ver. Colocaron los cristales líquidos entre dos piezas de vidrio y los iluminaron con una luz especial. Esto hizo que los cristales giraran en patrones rayados y coloridos que se mueven sin parar, como una animación en bucle. Su estudio se publicó en septiembre de 2023.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que el movimiento de un cristal temporal puede verse a simple vista. Esto muestra una nueva forma de crear materiales que cambian siguiendo un patrón predecible sin detenerse. Estos cristales podrían usarse para hacer que el dinero sea más difícil de falsificar con patrones móviles visibles bajo luz. También podrían ayudar a almacenar grandes cantidades de información digital en espacios pequeños.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos planean explorar más usos para estos cristales temporales visibles. Quieren crear patrones más complejos apilando varios cristales y encontrar otras aplicaciones prácticas. Esta investigación podría llevar a nuevos materiales para seguridad y almacenamiento de datos.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Por primera vez, los científicos han creado un cristal temporal visible, abriendo nuevas posibilidades para proteger el dinero y almacenar datos avanzados.

articles.title: My clothes wouldn't fit in my new flat - so I invented Vinted
articles.summary: Milda Mitkutė tells the BBC how a simple idea to sell her unwanted clothes became a billion dollar business.
articles.content:
“Oh my god, I have so much stuff...”

Ever looked around your room and felt like this? Stuff piling up on every surface, spilling out of wardrobes and drawers?

For Milda Mitkutė her mountain of clothing became a real problem, as it does for many of us, when she had to move flat.

“I counted about 300 items in total, I mean shoes, dresses, skirts, trousers, jeans and everything. I realised I can take only 100 because my new closet in my new apartment is like three times smaller!”

What happened next led to the creation of a billion dollar business and Lithuania’s first ever unicorn close unicorna privately owned start up company which is valued at over a billion dollars - known in the UK as Vinted.

The app now has over 16 million users in the UK alone and the chances are if you buy or sell clothes online you will have come across it.
articles.reasoning: The article describes the creation of Vinted, a successful platform that enables millions to buy and sell unwanted clothes, promoting sustainable consumption and reducing waste. This has broad societal impact by encouraging circular fashion and reducing environmental harm, supported by clear context and significance.
articles.personality_title: How a Move Sparked the Creation of Vinted, a Billion-Dollar Clothes App
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Milda Mitkutė faced a common problem when moving to a smaller flat: she had too many clothes and not enough space. Like many people, her wardrobe was overflowing with hundreds of items.

**What happened** – Realizing she could only keep about a third of her clothes, Milda came up with the idea to sell the rest online. This simple solution turned into Vinted, an app launched in Lithuania that helps people buy and sell second-hand clothes easily.

**Impact** – Today, Vinted is valued at over a billion dollars and is the first big tech company from Lithuania to reach this milestone. In the UK alone, more than 16 million people use the app. Vinted helps reduce waste by encouraging people to reuse clothes instead of throwing them away.

**What's next step** – Vinted plans to keep growing its user base and improve its platform to make buying and selling clothes even simpler. This could lead to more sustainable shopping habits worldwide.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A problem with too many clothes led Milda Mitkutė to create Vinted, a popular app that helps millions buy and sell clothes and supports a more sustainable way to shop.
articles.personality_title_fr: Comment un déménagement a inspiré la création de Vinted, une application valant un milliard
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Milda Mitkutė a rencontré un problème courant lors de son déménagement : elle avait trop de vêtements et pas assez de place. Comme beaucoup de gens, sa garde-robe débordait de centaines d’articles.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – En réalisant qu’elle ne pouvait garder qu’un tiers de ses vêtements, Milda a eu l’idée de vendre le reste en ligne. Cette solution simple a donné naissance à Vinted, une application lancée en Lituanie qui aide les gens à acheter et vendre des vêtements d’occasion facilement.

**Impact** – Aujourd’hui, Vinted est valorisée à plus d’un milliard de dollars et est la première grande entreprise technologique lituanienne à atteindre ce cap. Rien qu’au Royaume-Uni, plus de 16 millions de personnes utilisent l’application. Vinted aide à réduire les déchets en encourageant la réutilisation des vêtements au lieu de les jeter.

**Prochaine étape** – Vinted prévoit d’agrandir sa communauté d’utilisateurs et d’améliorer sa plateforme pour rendre l’achat et la vente de vêtements encore plus simples. Cela pourrait encourager des habitudes d’achat plus durables dans le monde entier.

**En une phrase** – Un problème de vêtements en trop a poussé Milda Mitkutė à créer Vinted, une application populaire qui aide des millions de personnes à acheter et vendre des habits tout en soutenant une consommation plus responsable.
articles.personality_title_es: Cómo una mudanza inspiró la creación de Vinted, una app valuada en mil millones
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Milda Mitkutė tuvo un problema común al mudarse: tenía demasiada ropa y poco espacio. Como muchas personas, su armario estaba lleno con cientos de prendas.

**Qué pasó** – Al darse cuenta de que solo podía quedarse con un tercio de su ropa, Milda tuvo la idea de vender el resto en línea. Esta solución sencilla se convirtió en Vinted, una aplicación lanzada en Lituania que ayuda a la gente a comprar y vender ropa de segunda mano fácilmente.

**Impacto** – Hoy, Vinted tiene un valor de más de mil millones de dólares y es la primera gran empresa tecnológica de Lituania en lograrlo. Solo en el Reino Unido, más de 16 millones de personas usan la app. Vinted ayuda a reducir los desechos al fomentar que la gente reutilice su ropa en lugar de tirarla.

**Próximo paso** – Vinted planea seguir creciendo y mejorar su plataforma para que comprar y vender ropa sea aún más fácil. Esto podría promover hábitos de compra más sostenibles en todo el mundo.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Un problema con demasiada ropa llevó a Milda Mitkutė a crear Vinted, una app popular que ayuda a millones a comprar y vender ropa y apoya una forma más sostenible de comprar.
